site_name: INDIAN CREEK INVESTMENT I I I, L L C

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
*One cream female goat was observed holding up its right front leg. The goat was partially weight-bearing while walking.
The facility identified the issue but failed to notify the attending veterinarian.
*The facility had two goats isolated for limping. The facility did not notify the attending veterinarian that the limping has
persisted despite administration of pain medications.
Failure to contact the attending veterinarian and to convey unimproved animal conditions within a timely manner can
delay diagnosis and treatment leading to unnecessary animal discomfort. Daily observations of all animals to assess their
health and well-being must be conducted. Daily observations may be accomplished by someone other than the attending
veterinarian provided that a mechanism of direct and frequent communication so that timely and accurate information on
problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.
To be corrected by COB 6-OCT-2023

An outdoor exhibit, housing one blue-and-yellow macaw and one green-winged macaw, did not have a complete barrier
fence. The north side of the barrier fence was broken and down on the ground. An incomplete barrier fence during times
of public exhibition can lead to animal or human injury. During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is
minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the
general viewing public so as to assure the safety of the animals and the public.
To be corrected by COB 6-OCT-2023

An outdoor enclosure, housing four ostriches, was constructed using fixed knot fencing. The fence was approximately 10
feet tall. Near the waterer, there was approximately three feet of the full-length fencing protruding into the ostrich
enclosure. There were multiple areas on this protruding portion of the fence where the metal wire strands were broken,
creating sharp points. Sharp points can lead to animal injury. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so
that they have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds.
To be corrected by 11-OCT-2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
KURT HAMMEL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
*One cream female goat was observed holding up its right front leg. The goat was partially weight-bearing while walking. 
The facility identified the issue but failed to notify the attending veterinarian.  
*The facility had two goats isolated for limping. The facility did not notify the attending veterinarian that the limping has 
persisted despite administration of pain medications.  
 
Failure to contact the attending veterinarian and to convey unimproved animal conditions within a timely manner can 
delay diagnosis and treatment leading to unnecessary animal discomfort. Daily observations of all animals to assess their 
health and well-being must be conducted. Daily observations may be accomplished by someone other than the attending 
veterinarian provided that a mechanism of direct and frequent communication so that timely and accurate information on 
problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. 
To be corrected by COB 6-OCT-2023 
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
An outdoor exhibit, housing one blue-and-yellow macaw and one green-winged macaw, did not have a complete barrier 
fence. The north side of the barrier fence was broken and down on the ground. An incomplete barrier fence during times 
of public exhibition can lead to animal or human injury. During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is 
minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the 
general viewing public so as to assure the safety of the animals and the public. 
To be corrected by COB 6-OCT-2023 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
An outdoor enclosure, housing four ostriches, was constructed using fixed knot fencing. The fence was approximately 10 
feet tall. Near the waterer, there was approximately three feet of the full-length fencing protruding into the ostrich 
enclosure. There were multiple areas on this protruding portion of the fence where the metal wire strands were broken, 
creating sharp points. Sharp points can lead to animal injury. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so

that they have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds. 
To be corrected by 11-OCT-2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KURT HAMMEL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
